title: How to Make Marshmallow Frosting

steps.headline: Bring the sugar and water to a boil.
steps.description: Combine 1 cup (200 g) of granulated sugar and 3 tablespoons (45 ml) of water in a small saucepan. Heat the mixture on medium-high until it comes to a boil, which should take approximately 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Cook the mixture until the sugar dissolves.
steps.description: Once the mixture comes to a boil, allow it to continue cooking until the sugar dissolves completely, which should take approximately 2 to 3 minutes. Be sure to stir the mixture constantly until the sugar dissolves. When the sugar has dissolved, take the pan off the heat.

steps.headline: Beat the egg whites with cream of tartar, vanilla, and salt.
steps.description: Add 2 large egg whites that are at room temperature, ¼ teaspoon (1 g) of cream of tartar, ¼ teaspoon (1 g) of salt, and 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla to the bowl of a stand mixer. Whip the mixture on medium-high until soft peaks form, which should take 1 to 2 minutes. To separate the egg whites from the yolk, break the egg against a flat surface, such as a countertop. Separate the egg in two over a bowl, allowing the yolk to fall into the lower half. Move the yolk back and forth so the white drips into the bowl below. Continue moving the yolk until all of the white is removed. You can also beat the egg white mixture with a handheld electric mixer if you prefer.

steps.headline: Pour the sugar syrup into the egg white mixture and beat until fluffy.
steps.description: Lower the mixer speed to medium, and slowly pour the warm sugar syrup into the egg white mixture. Keep beating the mixture until it cools and has a fluffy texture, which should take about 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Spread the frosting immediately.
steps.description: Once the frosting reaches the right consistency, it is ready to spread. It’s best used immediately, so smooth it over your cake or cupcakes as soon as you’re finished mixing it.

parts.name: Whipping Up Marshmallow Frosting with Marshmallows

steps.headline: Bring the sugar and water to a boil.
steps.description: Add 1 ¼ cup (250 g) of sugar and ½ cup (118 g) of water to a small saucepan. Heat the mixture on medium-high until it comes to a boil, which should take about 3 to 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Heat the sugar mixture until it reaches soft ball stage.
steps.description: Place a candy thermometer in the pan while it boils to monitor the mixture’s temperature. Stir the mixture frequently until the syrup reaches 235°F (112°C), which should take about 5 to 7 minutes. If you don’t have a candy thermometer, you’ll know the mixture has reached the right temperature when you drop a small bit of it in ice water and it forms a soft ball.

steps.headline: Break the marshmallows into pieces and add them to the syrup.
steps.description: When the syrup has reached the right temperature, take the pan off the heat. Tear 18 large marshmallows into small pieces and drop them into the warm syrup.

steps.headline: Let the marshmallows sit for several minutes.
steps.description: Once you’ve added the marshmallow pieces to the syrup, don’t stir the mixture. Allow the marshmallows to sit in the warm syrup for 1 to 2 minutes, so the marshmallows have time to soften and melt.

steps.headline: Pour the marshmallow mixture over the egg whites.
steps.description: After the marshmallows have softened and melted in the syrup, slowly add it to an egg white that’s been beaten to stiff peaks. Beat the mixture on medium-high with a handheld electric mixer to fully blend the two.

steps.headline: Beat the mixture until it reaches the right consistency.
steps.description: Continue mixing the frosting on medium-high until it is thick enough to spread easily. If it becomes too thick, mix in a few drops of water to thin it out.

steps.headline: Smooth the frosting over cupcakes immediately.
steps.description: The frosting can thicken up if you don’t use it right away. Spread it on your cupcakes or cake as soon as you finish mixing it.

parts.name: Mixing Up Marshmallow Frosting with Marshmallow Creme

steps.headline: Combine butter, marshmallow cream, and vanilla.
steps.description: Add ¼ cup (57 g) of softened butter, 7 ounces (199 g) of marshmallow cream, and 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla to a small bowl. Beat the mixture on medium with an electric mixer until it is well blended. You can mix the frosting in a stand mixer if you prefer. You can substitute margarine for the butter.

steps.headline: Slowly add in the sugar.
steps.description: You’ll need 16 ounces (454 g) of powdered sugar for the frosting. Add a little of it in at a time, and beat the mixture on low after each addition until all of the sugar is fully incorporated.

steps.headline: Mix in the milk.
steps.description: Once all of the sugar is incorporated, pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of milk into the bowl. Beat the mixture until the milk is fully incorporated. If the frosting still isn’t spreadable, add another tablespoon of milk (15 ml) and mix again.

steps.headline: Spread over the baked goods of your choice.
steps.description: When the frosting reaches the right consistency, it’s best to use it right away. Use a knife or offset spatula to smooth it over cupcakes or a cake, and enjoy.

text: Preparing Classic Marshmallow Frosting Bring the sugar and water to a boil. Combine 1 cup (200 g) of granulated sugar and 3 tablespoons (45 ml) of water in a small saucepan. Heat the mixture on medium-high until it comes to a boil, which should take approximately 3 minutes. Cook the mixture until the sugar dissolves. Once the mixture comes to a boil, allow it to continue cooking until the sugar dissolves completely, which should take approximately 2 to 3 minutes. Be sure to stir the mixture constantly until the sugar dissolves. When the sugar has dissolved, take the pan off the heat. Beat the egg whites with cream of tartar, vanilla, and salt. Add 2 large egg whites that are at room temperature, ¼ teaspoon (1 g) of cream of tartar, ¼ teaspoon (1 g) of salt, and 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla to the bowl of a stand mixer. Whip the mixture on medium-high until soft peaks form, which should take 1 to 2 minutes. To separate the egg whites from the yolk, break the egg against a flat surface, such as a countertop. Separate the egg in two over a bowl, allowing the yolk to fall into the lower half. Move the yolk back and forth so the white drips into the bowl below. Continue moving the yolk until all of the white is removed. You can also beat the egg white mixture with a handheld electric mixer if you prefer. Pour the sugar syrup into the egg white mixture and beat until fluffy. Lower the mixer speed to medium, and slowly pour the warm sugar syrup into the egg white mixture. Keep beating the mixture until it cools and has a fluffy texture, which should take about 5 minutes. Spread the frosting immediately. Once the frosting reaches the right consistency, it is ready to spread. It’s best used immediately, so smooth it over your cake or cupcakes as soon as you’re finished mixing it. Whipping Up Marshmallow Frosting with Marshmallows Bring the sugar and water to a boil. Add 1 ¼ cup (250 g) of sugar and ½ cup (118 g) of water to a small saucepan. Heat the mixture on medium-high until it comes to a boil, which should take about 3 to 5 minutes. Heat the sugar mixture until it reaches soft ball stage. Place a candy thermometer in the pan while it boils to monitor the mixture’s temperature. Stir the mixture frequently until the syrup reaches 235°F (112°C), which should take about 5 to 7 minutes. If you don’t have a candy thermometer, you’ll know the mixture has reached the right temperature when you drop a small bit of it in ice water and it forms a soft ball. Break the marshmallows into pieces and add them to the syrup. When the syrup has reached the right temperature, take the pan off the heat. Tear 18 large marshmallows into small pieces and drop them into the warm syrup. Let the marshmallows sit for several minutes. Once you’ve added the marshmallow pieces to the syrup, don’t stir the mixture. Allow the marshmallows to sit in the warm syrup for 1 to 2 minutes, so the marshmallows have time to soften and melt. Pour the marshmallow mixture over the egg whites. After the marshmallows have softened and melted in the syrup, slowly add it to an egg white that’s been beaten to stiff peaks. Beat the mixture on medium-high with a handheld electric mixer to fully blend the two. Beat the mixture until it reaches the right consistency. Continue mixing the frosting on medium-high until it is thick enough to spread easily. If it becomes too thick, mix in a few drops of water to thin it out. Smooth the frosting over cupcakes immediately. The frosting can thicken up if you don’t use it right away. Spread it on your cupcakes or cake as soon as you finish mixing it. Mixing Up Marshmallow Frosting with Marshmallow Creme Combine butter, marshmallow cream, and vanilla. Add ¼ cup (57 g) of softened butter, 7 ounces (199 g) of marshmallow cream, and 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla to a small bowl. Beat the mixture on medium with an electric mixer until it is well blended. You can mix the frosting in a stand mixer if you prefer. You can substitute margarine for the butter. Slowly add in the sugar. You’ll need 16 ounces (454 g) of powdered sugar for the frosting. Add a little of it in at a time, and beat the mixture on low after each addition until all of the sugar is fully incorporated. Mix in the milk. Once all of the sugar is incorporated, pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of milk into the bowl. Beat the mixture until the milk is fully incorporated. If the frosting still isn’t spreadable, add another tablespoon of milk (15 ml) and mix again. Spread over the baked goods of your choice. When the frosting reaches the right consistency, it’s best to use it right away. Use a knife or offset spatula to smooth it over cupcakes or a cake, and enjoy.
sentences: Preparing Classic Marshmallow Frosting Bring the sugar and water to a boil.
Combine 1 cup (200 g) of granulated sugar and 3 tablespoons (45 ml) of water in a small saucepan.
Heat the mixture on medium-high until it comes to a boil, which should take approximately 3 minutes.
Cook the mixture until the sugar dissolves.
Once the mixture comes to a boil, allow it to continue cooking until the sugar dissolves completely, which should take approximately 2 to 3 minutes.
Be sure to stir the mixture constantly until the sugar dissolves.
When the sugar has dissolved, take the pan off the heat.
Beat the egg whites with cream of tartar, vanilla, and salt.
Add 2 large egg whites that are at room temperature, ¼ teaspoon (1 g) of cream of tartar, ¼ teaspoon (1 g) of salt, and 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla to the bowl of a stand mixer.
Whip the mixture on medium-high until soft peaks form, which should take 1 to 2 minutes.
To separate the egg whites from the yolk, break the egg against a flat surface, such as a countertop.
Separate the egg in two over a bowl, allowing the yolk to fall into the lower half.
Move the yolk back and forth so the white drips into the bowl below.
Continue moving the yolk until all of the white is removed.
You can also beat the egg white mixture with a handheld electric mixer if you prefer.
Pour the sugar syrup into the egg white mixture and beat until fluffy.
Lower the mixer speed to medium, and slowly pour the warm sugar syrup into the egg white mixture.
Keep beating the mixture until it cools and has a fluffy texture, which should take about 5 minutes.
Spread the frosting immediately.
Once the frosting reaches the right consistency, it is ready to spread.
It’s best used immediately, so smooth it over your cake or cupcakes as soon as you’re finished mixing it.
Whipping Up Marshmallow Frosting with Marshmallows Bring the sugar and water to a boil.
Add 1 ¼ cup (250 g) of sugar and ½ cup (118 g) of water to a small saucepan.
Heat the mixture on medium-high until it comes to a boil, which should take about 3 to 5 minutes.
Heat the sugar mixture until it reaches soft ball stage.
Place a candy thermometer in the pan while it boils to monitor the mixture’s temperature.
Stir the mixture frequently until the syrup reaches 235°F (112°C), which should take about 5 to 7 minutes.
If you don’t have a candy thermometer, you’ll know the mixture has reached the right temperature when you drop a small bit of it in ice water and it forms a soft ball.
Break the marshmallows into pieces and add them to the syrup.
When the syrup has reached the right temperature, take the pan off the heat.
Tear 18 large marshmallows into small pieces and drop them into the warm syrup.
Let the marshmallows sit for several minutes.
Once you’ve added the marshmallow pieces to the syrup, don’t stir the mixture.
Allow the marshmallows to sit in the warm syrup for 1 to 2 minutes, so the marshmallows have time to soften and melt.
Pour the marshmallow mixture over the egg whites.
After the marshmallows have softened and melted in the syrup, slowly add it to an egg white that’s been beaten to stiff peaks.
Beat the mixture on medium-high with a handheld electric mixer to fully blend the two.
Beat the mixture until it reaches the right consistency.
Continue mixing the frosting on medium-high until it is thick enough to spread easily.
If it becomes too thick, mix in a few drops of water to thin it out.
Smooth the frosting over cupcakes immediately.
The frosting can thicken up if you don’t use it right away.
Spread it on your cupcakes or cake as soon as you finish mixing it.
Mixing Up Marshmallow Frosting with Marshmallow Creme Combine butter, marshmallow cream, and vanilla.
Add ¼ cup (57 g) of softened butter, 7 ounces (199 g) of marshmallow cream, and 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla to a small bowl.
Beat the mixture on medium with an electric mixer until it is well blended.
You can mix the frosting in a stand mixer if you prefer.
You can substitute margarine for the butter.
Slowly add in the sugar.
You’ll need 16 ounces (454 g) of powdered sugar for the frosting.
Add a little of it in at a time, and beat the mixture on low after each addition until all of the sugar is fully incorporated.
Mix in the milk.
Once all of the sugar is incorporated, pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of milk into the bowl.
Beat the mixture until the milk is fully incorporated.
If the frosting still isn’t spreadable, add another tablespoon of milk (15 ml) and mix again.
Spread over the baked goods of your choice.
When the frosting reaches the right consistency, it’s best to use it right away.
Use a knife or offset spatula to smooth it over cupcakes or a cake, and enjoy.
